trans-unit.source: title: Walkthrough sample ports from OpenGL ES 2.0
trans-unit.target: title: Walkthrough sample ports from OpenGL ES 2.0

trans-unit.source: description: This set of topics walks a number of OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline porting scenarios of differing complexity.
trans-unit.target: description: This set of topics walks a number of OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline porting scenarios of differing complexity.

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough sample ports from OpenGL ES 2.0
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough sample ports from OpenGL ES 2.0

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: This set of topics walks a number of OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline porting scenarios of differing complexity.
trans-unit.target: This set of topics walks a number of OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline porting scenarios of differing complexity.

trans-unit.source: For the first porting exercise, we'll start with the basics: bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.
trans-unit.target: For the first porting exercise, we'll start with the basics: bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.
